subject: RE: [junit] Again... with testing interfaces...
msgSnippet: Joe and Group: I ve thought about this some more.  While the situation below works, it still doesn t meet one of the goals I had when asking the original
messageBody:
Joe and Group:

I've thought about this some more. While the situation below works, it
still doesn't meet one of the goals I had when asking the original
question.

What I was attempting to achieve was the following:

If a developer writes a new class Y, which extends X (which implements
I), it would be nice if she only had to extend TX, override TX's factory
method, createX(), and have it return a Y instead. Since TX.TI would be
set up in such a way that TX.TI.createI() calls TX.createX(), TY would
end up with a suite which would run the inherited tests from TI against
a Y, and the tests for TX against a Y.

This just means that a developer doesn't have to look back in the class
heirarchy to see what interfaces have been implemented to get their test
classes setup properly for testing the default functionality (i.e. that
which exists before any methods are overriden, etc.).

This is a rare case for me right now, but as I was backfilling (I know,
ouch) some test cases, I noticed it would save me a bit of time if I
could set this up and it got me thinking / experimenting.

The approach below doesn't seem to gain me anything over the inner class
approach. The seem equivalent with the exception of the number of test
classes that you end up with. Am I misled?

Thanks again for the response.

Cheers,

Tom

-----Original Message-----
From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbrains@...]
Sent: Friday, March 19, 2004 1:33 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Again... with testing interfaces...


Thomas Robbs wrote:

> Imagine an interface I. Class X implements I. Class Y
extends X.

If you want to test whether X and Y each correctly respect the
contract
of I, then build an Abstract Test Case for I (TI) which you
extend to
TXAsI and TYAsI, two separate suites that create an X and a Y,
respectively, and hand it to the tests in TI.

TI is abstract and defines all the tests for the methods in I
plus
abstract creation methods.

TXAsI extends TI and implements the creation methods to return X

objects. TYAsI does the corresponding for Y.

If Y does not change any of the I-related behavior in X, then
TYAsI
duplicates TXAsI. That's not necessarily a /bad/ thing, but it's
worth
seeing.

If X or Y provide additional testable behavior beyond the
contract of I,
then add separate test suites for each.

I don't like the nested class approach, and it seems to be
vexing you,
so I vote to abandon it.
--
J. B. Rainsberger,
Diaspar Software Services
